awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Pteridological Collections Consortium: An integrative approach to pteridophyte diversity over the last 420 million years
awd_abstract_narration:
Ferns and their relatives ("pteridophytes") arose approximately 420 million years ago and were the dominant plant groups for hundreds of millions of years afterwards. Today the pteridophytes are outnumbered by the diversity and abundance of other plant groups, such as those that bear flowers, but they remain diverse (with around 12,000 species), ecologically important, and are found throughout the world. This Thematic Collections Network (TCN) brings together 9 core institutions whose goal is to make digital images and data on the distribution and biology of 1.6 million fossil and modern ferns and their relatives available to researchers. This effort includes 39 US Museums and Herbaria that will provide on-line access of collections data to researchers worldwide who will be able to address pressing questions about the evolution, distribution, and biology of land plants.  This project would train students and reach the public through teacher training opportunities, the development of curriculum and education boxes and through the production of informative science videos. 

The Pteridological Collections Consortium TCN is an interdisciplinary initiative that will database, image, and disseminate information on an unprecedented number of extant and fossil pteridophyte specimens. The combining of neo- and paleobotanical collections data will produce an online resource via a Symbiota framework to enable research on the distribution, ecology, genetics, and deep-time evolution of an important group of vascular plants. Pteridophytes are important because they 1) are relatively diverse and have extensive global distributions, 2) are associated with evolutionary innovations that shaped adaptations to terrestrial ecosystems, 3) they are sensitive to local environmental conditions and play important roles in modern communities, and 4) they have an excellent fossil record for addressing deep-time questions. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Pteridological Collections Consortium (PCC) TCN is a three-year digitization project led by the University of California at Berkeley, in collaboration with 35 U.S. natural history institutions, including The New York Botanical Garden (NYBG), and its two subaward institutions, Rutgers the State University of New Jersey and the University of Texas at Austin. The PCC project's primary goal is to image and digitize the metadata for over 1.6 million herbarium and 100,000 fossil pteridophyte specimens, and to provide free, online access to them through a dedicated PCC data portal, for use by researchers, educators, and the general public.

Pteridophytes (spore-bearing ferns and their relatives) have existed on Earth for over 420 million years and played a critical role in the formation of terrestrial ecosystems. Herbarium and fossil collections curated within natural history institutions document the occurrence of these plants on Earth over time, enabling the study of their diversity, geographic distribution, and evolution. By digitizing them and integrating their data online, this project has provided researchers worldwide with access to an unprecedented resource to study pteridophytes and their role in the evolution and persistence of terrestrial ecosystems, especially in response to potential environmental change.

As one of the largest pteridophyte herbarium collections in the United States, NYBG has successfully completed its project objectives to capture high-resolution images of over 185,700 specimens, digitize metadata for 150,000, and georeference 18,800. The digitization work was performed by one Lead Digitizer and three Herbarium Student Interns, all of whom received professional development training in herbarium curation best practices and digitization protocols, such as the use of the herbarium collections management system, data entry standards, use of specimen photography equipment, and georeferencing best practices. Additionally, they attended numerous seminars and tours by NYBG Science, Conservation, Horticulture, and Humanities staff, introducing these early-STEM-career individuals to potential career paths in biology, botany, horticulture, humanities, and museum studies.

Also contributing to this project were numerous community scientists, both local and global, who assisted with onsite specimen imaging and offsite metadata digitization. NYBG hosted two WeDigBio community science events and multiple specimen transcription expeditions through the crowdsourcing platform DIGIVOL, resulting in 20,000 specimen labels transcribed by community scientists worldwide.

Despite setbacks experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic preventing students from working on campus, Rutgers University's large herbarium undergraduate internship program provided project-funded and for-university-credit work for nearly 100 undergraduate students who were trained in all aspects of herbarium pteridophyte specimen digitization. In total, they imaged over 16,000 specimens, digitized metadata for over 11,800, and georeferenced 328.

Similarly, the University of Texas at Austin employed seven project-funded undergraduate students who imaged 25,800 specimens, digitized metadata for 16,000, and georeferenced 4,000. Students received professional development training in specimen metadata capture and use of the herbarium collections management system, and they received individual mentoring weekly on the taxonomy and biology of the plants being digitized.

The specimen data and images generated by this award and the PCC project as a whole are now openly accessible through several online data portals including the project-specific PCC data portal, the Global Biodiversity Information Facility, Integrated Digitized Biocollections, and NYBG's Virtual Herbarium (NYBG data only).
